title-group.article-title: Modeling impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites by artificial neural networks

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Saveh Branch, Islamic Azad University, Saveh, Iran
2Department of Materials Engineering, Imam Khomeini International University, Qazvin, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Ali Nazari, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Saveh Branch, Islamic Azad University, Saveh, Iran Email: alinazari84@aut.ac.ir

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this article, Charpy impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites in both crack divider and crack arrester configurations has been investigated. In both configurations, an analytical investigation has been carried out to evaluate the effects of layer thickness on impact resistance of the specimens. A model based on artificial neural networks for predicting impact resistance of the specimens has been presented. For the purpose of building the model, training and testing usingexperimental results from 126 specimens produced from two basic composites were conducted. The data used in the multilayer feed forward neural networks models are arranged in a format of seven input parameters that cover the thickness of layers,the number of layers, the adhesive type, the crack tip configuration, the content of SiC particles, the content ofmethacrylated butadiene–styrene particles, and the test trial number. According to these input parameters, in the neuralnetworks model, the impact resistance of each specimen was predicted. The training and testing results in the neuralnetwork model have shown a strong potential for predicting impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Aluminum laminates are well suited for aerospace applications as they exhibit higher impact strengths compared to most monolithic and other composite materials.1,2 Most investigations in this field, however, are focused on the behavior of laminates under static loading,3–5 while only a limited amount of work has been carried on laminates subjected to impact loading.6–8 The original works in this field are those of Kaufman9 and Goolsby10 who compared the static fracture toughness of monolithic aluminum with that of laminates. Those researchers reported the superior toughness of the laminates compared to that of the monolithic aluminum (Al). Manoharan et al.11 investigated the fracture behavior of a two-layer laminated structure, which consisted of an unreinforced-Al layer and a discontinuously reinforced aluminum (DRA) layer. They reported a 10% increase in the initiation and 250% increase in the propagation fracture toughness in a double-layer aluminum/DRA compared to a monolayer DRA.

Over the past two decades, a different modeling method based on artificial neural networks (ANNs) has become popular and used by many researchers for a wide range of engineering applications. ANNs are a family of massively parallel architectures that solve difficult problems via the cooperation of highly interconnected but simple computing elements (or artificial neurons). Basically, the processing elements of a neural network are analogous to the neurons in the brain, which consist of many simple computational elements arranged in several layers.12 Some models have been recently proposed to predict Charpy impact behavior using neural network;13,14 these models are at their infancy and need to be extended. The main works done on engineering structures in this area include the prediction of concrete properties by ANNs. Yeh15 applied the ANNs for predicting properties of high-performance concretes. Lai and Serra16 predicted the strength of concrete using the neural network. Lee17 used single and multiple ANN architectures for predicting the concrete strength. Hong-Guang and Ji-Zong18 proposed a method to predict 28-day compressive strength of concrete using multilayer feed-forward neural networks. Dias and Pooliyadda19 utilized back propagation neural networks to predict the strength and slump of ready mixed and high-strength concretes in which chemical admixtures and/or mineral additives were used. Pala et al.20 developed a model for predicting long-term effects of fly ash and silica fume on compressive strength of concrete using neural networks. Oztas et al.21 constructed a model with two hidden layers for predicting the compressive strength and slump of high-strength concrete using neural network. Akkurt et al.22 utilized genetic algorithms and ANNs for modeling the compressive strength of cement mortar. In the study, the common three layer feed-forward type of ANNs is used. Mukherjee and Biswas23 constructed a model with two hidden layers feed-forward type of ANNs for predicting the mechanical behavior of concrete at high temperature. In addition, in our previous works,24–26 the effects of Cr2O3, TiO2, and Fe2O3 nanoparticles on physical and mechanical properties of high-strength concrete have been modeled by ANNs. In all these studies, a model with two hidden layer feed-forward type of ANNs for predicting the physical and mechanical behaviors of concrete containing different amounts of nanoparticles was built. All the results showed that ANNs are capable to predict the properties of concrete with an excellent accuracy. Finally, the ductile-to-brittle transition temperature of functionally graded steels in both crack divider and crack arrester configurations was modeled by ANNs in our previous work.27 The results showed that this property could be predicted by ANNs with an excellent accuracy. Therefore, all the results obtained from our literature survey show that ANN is a good software tool to predict the properties of engineering materials such as the impact resistance of aluminum/epoxy-laminated composites in this study.

The aim of this study is to predict impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites in both crack divider and crack arrester configurations with ANNs. Totally, 126 data of Charpy impact tests in different temperatures were collected, trained, and tested by means of ANNs. The obtained results have been compared with experimental ones to evaluate the software power for predicting the impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p: A commercially pure Al plate was used as the base material and a two-part epoxy polymer, including resin and curing agent, was incorporated as the adhesive material. The adhesive was modified using core-shell rubber particles and silicon carbide particles (SiC). Core-shell rubber particles comprises a methacrylated butadiene–styrene (MBS) copolymer with a nominal diameter of less than 350 nm.

The average particle size of the utilized SiC particles was 10 µm. The additive content was varied from 5 to 15 vol.%. The designation for each formulation used in this study is outlined in Table 1. Table 1.
Composition and nomenclature of materials investigated
Designation Material Modifier type Modifier content (vol.%)
Neat epoxy Neat epoxy None 0
MBS(5) Rubber-modified epoxy Core-shell rubber particles 5
MBS(10) 10
MBS(15) 15
SiC(5) SiC-filled epoxy Silicon carbide 5
SiC(10) 10
SiC(15) 15

Three types of laminates, including 2-, 5-, and 10-layer specimens, along with the monolithic specimen were considered for studying the influence of laminate architecture on the impact resistance. A 10-mm thick aluminum bar was used to make the monolithic specimen. The same material was hot-rolled down to different thicknesses for preparation of the laminates. The layer thickness values in 2-, 5-, and 10-layer specimens were 5, 2, and 1 mm, respectively. The thickness of the layers was selected such that the total aluminum thickness in each laminate was 10 mm and all layers in each laminate had the same thickness. All aluminum bars were solution heat-treated at 400 C followed by a cold water quench.

The impact behavior of laminated composites was evaluated using Charpy impact test using standard sized specimens according to the ASTM E23.28 Figure 1(a) shows the impact specimens investigated in this study. Charpy impact testing was conducted on a pendulum impact tester using a maximum capacity of 300 J. To carry out the test, the standard specimen is supported at its two ends on an anvil and struck on the opposite face to the notch by a pendulum, as shown in Figure 2. The specimen is fractured and the pendulum swings through, the height of the swing being a measure of the amount of energy absorbed in fracturing the specimen. Conventionally, three specimens are tested and the results averaged. Figure 1.
(a) Dimensions of Charpy impact specimen and schematic representation of Charpy impact specimens’ preparation in (b) crack divider and (c) crack arrester configurations. Figure 2.
Charpy testing machine.

Impact specimens were notched perpendicular to the interface of the layers using a diamond saw in both crack divider (Figure 1(b)) and crack arrester (Figure 1(c)) configurations. The notches were 2 mm deep.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Impact energy values of the composites are given in Table 2. The calculation method of uncertainty was in accordance to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)29 method for Charpy impact test machines and it is as follows. A Charpy laboratory will typically compute the sample mean (CV) and sample standard deviation (SD) of n specimens of the test material using Equations (1) and (2): Table 2.
Charpy impact resistance of the laminated composites (kJ/m2)
Notch tip configuration Designation Two-layer composites Five-layer composites 10-layer composites
Crack divider Neat epoxy 235 ± 14 315 ± 18 412 ± 28
MBS(5) 238 ± 16 349 ± 20 451 ± 26
MBS(10) 245 ± 17 331 ± 19 408 ± 24
MBS(15) 236 ± 18 321 ± 21 226 ± 23
SiC(5) 242 ± 16 329 ± 21 398 ± 22
SiC(10) 261 ± 15 318 ± 24 376 ± 24
SiC(15) 269 ± 19 308 ± 22 354 ± 26
Crack arrester Neat epoxy 472 ± 24 591 ± 30 752 ± 38
MBS(5) 470 ± 22 622 ± 35 791 ± 39
MBS(10) 485 ± 27 636 ± 32 754 ± 38
MBS(15) 491 ± 21 616 ± 34 341 ± 25
SiC(5) 475 ± 24 599 ± 31 782 ± 39
SiC(10) 478 ± 24 606 ± 30 721 ± 34
SiC(15) 482 ± 26 609 ± 32 654 ± 36
where CVi represents the values of Charpy impact energy in each experiment.

The degrees of freedom (df) associated with the sample standard deviation, s, are n − 1. It is important to note that sincludes all sources of random error, including machine variability, material variability, and the typical variations expected when following the standard test procedure. The individual components of the random error cannot be estimated separately in the case of destructive impact testing. (Multiple measurements on the same specimen are needed to do this.) In addition, random errors (unlike systematic errors) do not remain constant during the measurement of n specimens; so, these errors do not result in a bias.29
The corrected mean CV (CVcorrected) value after applying systematic effect could be written as:29

where b∧ is the difference between the verification result for the test machine and the certified value of the verification specimens and e∧systematic the systematic errors due to all other factors that are not already included in the machine bias.
Assuming all the terms in CVcorrected are independent, the combined standard uncertainty of CVcorrected is:29
where u(CVcorrected) is the combined standard uncertainty of CVcorrected, and u(b∧) and u(e∧systematic) theuncertainty associated with b∧ and e∧systematic, respectively.
An uncertainty interval with 100(1 − α)% coverage probability (α is 0.05 for 95% coverage) is given by:

where t1-α2.dfeff is found in a t-table.29 Using a t-table, we get a coverage factor of 2.012 for testing five specimens. NIST29 has proposed that b∧=-4.2J, e∧systematic=3J, and u(e∧systematic)=0.6J for Charpy impact energies inthe range of our values in this study. As shown inTable 2, the uncertainty for all the specimens has a reasonable value which implies that the impact resistance of the specimens can be acceptable for consideration.

As seen in Table 2, all laminated composites possess significantly higher impact energies compared to the monolithic aluminum specimen (185 ± 13 kJ/m2). As seen, the laminates absorbed higher energy during the fracture under impact loading than that of the monolithic specimen. This observation can be attributed to the influence of interfaces introduced in the laminates. The triaxial stress field ahead of the crack tips may cause debonding at the up front interface(s). This in turn, reduces the crack driving force due to the need for crack renucleation in the next layer(s).30,31 It may also cause a possible transition from plane strain to plane stress that results in further plastic deformation and thus, extra energy absorption in the aluminum layers.32,33 In either case, the impact resistance is improved.

sec.title: Discussions
sec.p: The variations in impact resistance of laminated composites in crack arrester configuration by changing the thickness of their constituent layers could be investigated from physical point of view.
If the monolithic region ahead of a notch tip could be considered as n elements, the total absorbed energy by a Charpy specimen, Et, can be obtained by Equation (6):

where Ee is the elastically absorbed energy by the specimen causing its elastic deformation, Et ' the main portion of the absorbed energy by a Charpy specimen, that is, portion of the energy which is consumed for plastic deformation, ∑i=1 N(2γ)i the energy required for separation of interface in unstable crack growth, and N the number of layers in which unstable crack growth occurs.

Calculation of each of these parts is not simply accessible and requires instrumented Charpy impact testing together with suitable mathematical models to calculate the Charpy impact energy of the specimen. As it mentioned above, the main portion of the energy is absorbed during plastic deformation of the specimen. It seems that in 5- and 10-layer specimens, all the constituent layers deform plastically, while in 2-layer specimens, some part of each layer contributes to the unstable crack growth. However, as it is indicated, the main factor in changing the absorbed energy is changing the stress condition from plane strain in 2-layer specimens to plane stress in 5- and 10-layer specimens. It could be assumed that the absorbed energy by each specimen is related to its plastic deformation zone. Since the plastic deformation zone is thickness-dependent, one may anticipate that the required force for its deformation is different. For plane strain condition, one may write:34
where ry is the radius of the plastic deformation zone, KI the mode-I stress intensity factor, σy the specimen’s yield stress, ν the Poisson’s ratio, and θ the angular position.
For plane stress condition, the radius of the plastic deformation zone is:34
Supposing the Poisson’s ratio equals 0.3, the ratio between net plane stress, fplane-strain to fplane-stress can be obtained by Equation (9):
Therefore, in ideal conditions, the required force (energy) for crack growth in the specimens with thinner specimens can be twofold to that of the specimens with thicker layers.

The variations in impact resistance of laminated composites in crack divider configuration by changing the thickness of their constituent layers could also be investigated from physical point of view.

If it is assumed that the un-cracked part of the monolithic specimen ahead of the notch is composed of n elements, impact energy of the monolithic specimen is the mean value of the impact energy of these n layers:
where CVi is the impact energy of each element. In fact,CVi is the CV of the specimen multiplied by a ratio of the plane stress condition to the plane strain condition, fi, i.e.

fi depends on the element position and the closer the element to the specimen edges, the higher the fi. To determine fi, by considering Equation (9) and supposing that the variation of the elements’ plastic zone size from the edges of the specimen to the center of that specimen obeys an exponential function, by applying the suitable boundary conditions and assuming that the origin of theCartesian coordinate is at the center of the specimen, one may write:
where x is the distance of each element with respect tothe center of the specimen and W the specimen thickness.
To calculate fPlane-stress and fPlane-strain, we have:
To satisfy Equation (13), we must have:
By applying the mean value theorem, it could be written:
where W2-t represents the thickness in which there exists a combination of plane stress and plane strain condition.
By substituting Equation (9) into Equation (10), fi could be determined as:

Equation (16) shows that the thinner the layer, the higher the fi in equivalent x. In other words, the required force (energy) for specimen’s fracture is increased or in the specimens with the thinner layers, the required energy for fracture is higher.

sec.title: Artificial neural networks
sec.p:
ANNs were developed to model the human brain.35 Even an ANN fairly simple and small in size when compared to the human brain has some powerful characteristics in knowledge and information processing because it is similar to the human brain. Therefore, an ANN can be a powerful tool for engineering applications.36 McCulloch and Pitts37 defined the artificial neurons for the first time and developed a neuron model, as shown in Figure 3. McCulloch and Pitts’37 network formed the basis for almost all later neural network models. Afterwards, Rosenblatt38 devised a machine called the perceptron that operated much in the same way as the human mind. Rosenblatt’s38 perceptrons consist of ‘sensory’ units connected to a single layer of McCulloch and Pitts37 neurons. Rumelhart et al.39 derived a learning algorithm for perceptron networks with constituted hidden units. Figure 3.
Architecture of applied neural network.
The weighted sums of the input components (net)j are calculated using Equation (17) as follows:

where (net)j is the weighted sum of the jth neuron for the input received from the preceding layer with n neurons, Wij the weight between the jth neuron in the previous layer, and xi the output of the ith neuron in the previouslayer,40 b a fix value as internal addition and ∑ the sum function. The output of the jth neuron (out)j is computed using Equation (18) with a sigmoid activation function as follows:41
where α is the constant used to control the slope of the semi-linear region. The sigmoid non-linearity activates in every layer except in the input layer.40

Levenberg Marquardt back propagation (LMBP) is often the fastest available back-propagation algorithm, and is highly recommended as a first-choice supervised algorithm, although it requires more memory than other algorithms. The standard LMBP training process can be described in the pseudocode of Figure 4.42 Figure 4.
Pseudo-code for LMBP algorithm.27

sec.title: Neural network model structure and parameters
sec.p:
ANN model is carried out in this research and has seven neurons in the input layer and one neuron in the output layer, as demonstrated in Figure 5. The values for input layers were the thickness of layers (T), the number oflayers (N), the adhesive type (A), the crack tip configuration (C), the content of SiC particles (S), the content of MBS particles (M), and the test trial number (NT). To achieve a more comprehensive model, more than 80 results were required. Therefore, all the three tests done on each of the 42 specimens were collected. Totally 126 data were gathered and to characterize these values, they were labeled as 1, 2, and 3 which means the first, second, and third tries on a specific specimen, respectively. Hence, the test trial number was considered as an input in the ANN models. The value for output layer was Charpy impact resistance (CVN). Two hidden layers with 10 and 8 neurons were used in the architecture of multilayer neural network because of their minimum absolute percentage error values for training and testing sets. The neurons of neighboring layers are completely interconnected by weights. Finally, the output layer neurons produce the network prediction as a result. From 126 collected data, 103 data were randomly chosen for training set and the other 23 data for testing one. Figure 5.
The system used in the ANN model.

In this study, the back-propagation training algorithm has been utilized in feed-forward two hidden layers. Back-propagation algorithm, as one of the most well-known training algorithms for the multilayer perceptron, is a gradient descent technique to minimize the error for a particular training pattern in which it adjust the weights by a small amount at a time.42 The non-linear sigmoid activation function was used in the hidden layer and the neuron outputs at the output one.Momentum and learning rate values were determined and the model was trained through iterations. The trained model was only tested with the input values and the predicted results were close to the experiment results. The values of parameters used in neural network model are given in Table 3. Table 3.
The values of parameters used in neural network model
Parameters ANN
Number of input layer units 7
Number of hidden layers 2
Number of first hidden layer units 10
Number of second hidden layer units 8
Number of output layer units 1
Momentum rate 0.88
Learning rate 0.70
Error after learning 0.000050
Learning cycle 30.000

To make a decision on the completion of the training processes, two termination states are declared: state 1 (ANN-I model) means that the training of neural network was ended when the maximum epoch of process reached (1000), while state 2 (ANN-II model) means the training ended when minimum error norm of network gained.

sec.title: ANNs’ results and discussion
sec.p: The performance of an ANN model mainly depends on the network architecture and parameter settings. One of the most difficult tasks in ANN studies is to find this optimal network architecture, which is based on the determination of number of optimal layers and neurons in the hidden layers by a trial-and-error approach. The assignment of initial weights and other related parameters may also influence the performance of the ANN to a great extent. However, there is no well-defined rule or procedure to have an optimal network architecture and parameter settings where the trial-and-error method still remains valid. This process is very time consuming.43–46

In this study, the Matlab ANN toolbox is used for ANN applications. To overcome optimization difficulty, a program has been developed in Matlab which handles the trial and error process automatically.43–46 The program tries various numbers of layers and neurons in the hidden layers both for the first and second hidden layers when the highest root mean squared error of the testing set, as the training of the testing set is achieved.43–46
In this study, the error arose during the training and testing in ANN-I and ANN-II models can be expressed as absolute fraction of variance (R2) which are calculated by Equation (19):47
where t is the target value and o the output value.

The performance of the ANN-I and ANN-II models is shown in Figure 6. The best value of R2 is 98.08% for training set in the ANN-II model. The minimum values of R2 are 91.57% for testing set in the ANN-I model. All R2 values show that the proposed ANN-I and ANN-II models are suitable and can predict CVN values very close to the experimental values.

ANNs are capable of learning and generalizing from examples and experiences.36 This makes ANNs a powerful tool for solving some of the complicated engineering problems.40 In this study, using these beneficial properties of ANNs in order to predict Charpy impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites without attempting any experiments, two different multilayer ANN architectures, namely ANN-I and ANN-II, were developed. In two models developed in ANN method, a multilayered feed forward neural network with a back propagation algorithm was used. The models were trained with input and output data. Using only the input data in trained models, the Charpy impact resistance of aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites was found. The Charpy impact resistance values predicted from training and testing, for ANN-I and ANN-II models, are very close to the experimental results similar to the works done in concrete area.40,42,48,49 Furthermore, according to the Charpy impact resistance results predicted using ANN-I and ANN-II models, the results of ANN-II model are closer to the experimental results. R2 values40 that are calculated for comparing experimental results with ANN-I and ANN-II model results have shown this situation.

list-item.p: The impact resistance of the aluminum–epoxy-laminated composites in both crack divider and crack arrester configurations was higher than that of monolithic aluminum specimen.
In both crack divider and crack arrester configurations, the impact resistance of the specimens depended on the number of layers together with the bonding strength of the utilized adhesive.
ANNs can be an alternative approach for the evaluation of the effect of layer’s number and bonding strength on CVN values of laminated composites.
Comparison between ANNs in terms of R2 showed that ANN models are capable of predicting suitable results for CVN values.
The optimization method used for this study resulted in achieving suitable R2 values and hence acceptable results.
From the predicted values from ANN models, it was found that the model is capable of designing composite structures for the future works.
